body: GUTIERREZ -- Gerald. The Board and Staff of Lincoln Center Theater are deeply saddened and mourn the death of our beloved colleague and esteemed Associate Director. Gerry performed theatrical miracles of direction on the Beaumont stage, most recently with his acclaimed production of ''Dinner at Eight''. His productions of ''Ivanov'' and ''Abe
title: Paid Notice: Deaths GUTIERREZ, GERALD

body: There's the struggle over the future of ground zero. There's the face-off between the city unions and a budget-conscious mayor. And then there's the coup against Councilman Lewis A. Fidler. Politics has small stories as well as big ones, and a small one broke 10 days ago when City Council members from Brooklyn voted 15 to 0 to replace Mr. Fidler as
title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: BROOKLYN UP CLOSE; Democrats to See if Two Heads Are Better Than One

body: The spot was in the heart of an urban bedlam, surrounded by the hurtling traffic of the Triborough Bridge, the smokestacks of Con Edison, the grim warrens of Rikers Island, the roar of La Guardia jets and three sewage treatment plants. Yet there hunched on a beach on South Brother Island in the East River, looking like old philosophers mulling a
title: So, You Were Expecting a Pigeon?; In City Bustle, Herons, Egrets and Ibises Find a Sanctuary

body: ''CHOCOLATE is the next coffee,'' confided one importer. ''Chocolate is the new olive oil,'' said a chocolatier. ''Chocolate now is where cheese was 10 years ago,'' a pastry chef asserted. In the beginning, there was wine. And there were wine tastings and wine snobs and wine-of-the-month clubs. Then olive oil, vinegar, cheese, coffee and butter
title: Hints of Wine? Chocolate Enters The Tasting Room

body: It is a brief but awkward conversation that William Ringwood, custodial engineer at New Utrecht High School in southern Brooklyn, tends to have at this time of year. A teacher just back from a long vacation will see him in the halls, assume that he has also been off for the summer, and say, ''Good to see you back.'' Mr. Ringwood's answer: ''I never
title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: NEW YORK SCHOOLS; The Long View From the Boiler Room

body: ON a muggy July day nine years ago, Jim Kennelly and two fellow firefighters plunged five or six times each to the bottom of Coney Island Creek, their eyes clenched against the filthy water, to rescue five unconscious people tangled inside a wheels-up car 10 feet down on the creek bed. ''When I broke the surface to go under water, it was eerie,
title: A Firefighter's Other Passion: Changing The Skyline

author: Steve Kurutz is a staff writer for Details magazine.
body: THE Belt Parkway, which stretches for 36 miles from Owls Head Park in Bay Ridge, Brooklyn, to Long Island, is a road as bold and monolithic as New York City itself. The highway, which was built by Robert Moses, is lined with concrete barriers and colossal traffic jams on weekends. Driving the Belt is like skirting along the very heart of urbanism.
title: In the Still of the Night

body: WITH their deep front porches and overhanging eaves, Midwood's predominantly shingled two-story houses with front yards and driveways feel more like suburbia than like Brooklyn. title: If You're Thinking of Living In/Midwood; Bustling Area With a Touch of Country

body: To the Editor: Re. ''A Newspaper of Record, Recorded'' (June 1), about a new project to make The Brooklyn Daily Eagle available on the Web: My parents had The Eagle delivered daily to our doorstep in Marine Park, and I've missed the paper ever since it went out of business when I was in my early teens. As Brooklyn's hometown paper, The Eagle was
title: Always Finding The Brooklyn Angle

body: ZUCKERMAN-Lucile K. Retired New York City public school teacher residing in Brooklyn, on April 28, 2003. She taught science at Marine Park Junior High School in Brooklyn for 25 years and was an active member of the United Federation of Teachers. She was a true New Yorker, the only one of her many siblings to remain in the city after her retirement.
title: Paid Notice: Deaths ZUCKERMAN, LUCILE K.

body: An off-duty police officer had three times the legal level of alcohol in his blood when his car collided with another car carrying a middle-aged couple in Brooklyn last week, in a crash that killed all three people, the police said yesterday. At first, investigators did not find any evidence that the officer, Michael McGibbon, 28, had been drinking
title: Officer in Fatal Crash Was Drunk, Test Finds

body: An off-duty police officer and a husband and wife on their way to work at a bakery were killed early yesterday when their cars collided at a Brooklyn intersection, the police said. The off-duty officer, Michael McGibbon, 28, was driving northwest on 65th Street in Bensonhurst at 4:48 a.m. when his car collided with one going southwest on 24th
title: Married Couple and Officer Are Killed When Cars Collide

body: Three men and three women gathered around a table Monday night and tied yellow identification cards around their necks with twine. With this, they became members of Group 5, crusading against homelessness in New York City. They said it was a sense of duty that had brought them to this large conference room in this downtown office building to help
title: No Door-to-Door in This Census; Volunteers Outnumber Subjects in Homeless Count
